Posts.Content: JenXX wrote: Hello all:  I had a full mastectomy of the right breast with removal of 4 lymph nodes (which were clear) 4 weeks ago and this week it seems like my fatigue has become worse than before.  Last week I went to Hawaii on a trip I had booked before the diagnosis - I took it easy, but was still pretty active.  I've been back a week and can't get out of bed in the morning, and after a cup of tea I'm unable to do really anything.  I haven't started chemo yet.  Has anyone else had this problem or have any ideas?  I'm supposed to be working 50% to keep my medical benefits but wasn't able to go in yesterday.  Thanks! Dx 7/28/2009, 2cm, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 03:04PM JenXX wrote: Thanks for all the useful comments - I appreciate it. A friend of mine had knee surgery same day as my Mx and said I had to up my protein which helps the body to create new tissue.  So I started adding more protein and felt better after about a week.  Tomorrow I start chemo so I will have all sorts of NEW fatigue issues, .... blech. Thanks, Jen

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 12:22PM JenXX wrote: I'm having the exact same issue.  I picked TC instead of AC because taxotere is supposed to be "gentler."  I had an absolutely miserable response to the 1st round and told my onco I didn't want to do any more.  In response, he reduced taxotere by 25% and prescribed Emend and the 2nd and 3rd rounds were much easier. My 4th round was worse than death.  I was actually praying for death.  My body is just not doing well on the chemo - and I would hate to suffer through 2 more rounds only to get cancer again in a few years like what has happened to so many others!  Even with chemo, you are likely to get it again - so what is the point of all the suffering?   And it's not just the suffering, which is typically short term.  I fear for the long term implications of chemo on my health. I think chemo is like setting loose a gang of wild monkeys with machetes in your house to get rid of a mouse.  At the end, the mouse is probably still there and now you have a wrecked house. I want to hear from folks who decided not to do chemo, or who cut theirs short like I am thinking of, and whether there was reoccurence.  I also want to hear from those who went through chemo and had reoccurence anyway.
